Estoy para votarla erronea.
La noticia no habla exclusivamente de vino. Lo hace de consumo de alcohol y drogas.
Os cuento. En universidad elegí una optativa que se llamaba El vino como alimento. Básicamente leíamos publicaciones científicas donde se demostraba los beneficios/perjuicios de la ingesta de vino.
Un consumo de vino tinto moderado y diario aporta beneficios a nivel cardio bascular por los polifenoles y otros componentes (también el de frutos rojos). Hay la paradoja francesa…

author: Victor Okechukwu
title: Naomi Osaka is eager to play the WTA 'big dogs' after coming from behind to win her opening match in Miami
text:
Naomi Osaka ended her winless drought since the Australian Open at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Open. The Japanese star survived a first-round scare after coming from behind to beat Ukrainian qualifier Yuliia Starodubtseva in the first round.
Osaka, who was the runners-up in the 2022 Miami Open, returned from injury to compete in the Sunshine Double. The former World No.1 suffered an abdominal injury which forced her to retire during her third-round match against Belinda Bencic. However, two weeks ago, she lost to Camila Osorio in the first round in Indian Wells.
She was aiming to bounce back in Miami after beginning the season by reaching the final of the Auckland Classics in the first week of the year. Despite the setback early into her first round tie, she bounced back in time to beat Starodubtseva 3-6, 6-4, 6-3 in 2 hours and 28 minutes in the Florida-based tournament.
After the match, she was asked if she could go further to winning more matches and perhaps winning the title. The Japanese star said that she was ready to play the big stars in the circuit at the tournament.
I want to play with the big dogs so bad, and I just see everyone playing so well, and I want to do the same. But I have to remember it’s a process.
Naomi Osaka said via[WTA]
Osaka now has an opportunity to extend her run at the Miami Open as she faces Liudmila Samsonova in the second round. Samsonova reached the quarterfinals of Indian Wells and earned her biggest win of the season by beating Jasmine Paolini in the fourth round.
Naomi Osaka began her opening round match very poorly as she was down 3-6, 2-4 against Yuliia Starodubtseva at the Miami Open. The Japanese star had to win four consecutive match points to beat the Ukrainian qualifier in the second set and then complete the turnaround in the third. She later revealed that her coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, was behind her comeback.
I knew that I wasn’t playing too well, but I thought, let me try to stay on the court as long as possible, because I consider Miami my home. When I reach maximum concentration, I completely forget what’s happening in the match; I’m in a bubble. My coach told me that I saved a break point when I was 2-5 down in the second set, and I had no idea. I try to play each point as if it’s the most important of the match when I’m in that state.
Naomi Osaka said
Osaka would take the hard lessons of her performance into the second round. The Japanese star was lucky that she was up against an inexperienced qualifier in the opening match, as a top player would never give her any chance for a comeback.
Naomi Osaka will be hoping to get into the latter stages of the Miami Open for the first time since 2022. The former World No.1 will take on Liudmila Samsonova in the second round, and if she does beat the Russian star, she will face 12th seed Daria Kasatkina in the third round of the WTA 1000 tournament.
With a win over Kasatkina, she will likely play either Ons Jabeur or Jasmine Paolini in the fourth round. A possible meeting with Coco Gauff awaits Osaka in the quarter-finals if she gets through.

author: Grace O'Connor - Health & Science Editor
title: Kentucky Measles Outbreak Fuels US Surge to 30-Year High
text:
Measles Resurgence: Why a Forgotten Generation Now Faces Renewed Risk – And What It Signals for Public Health The United States is on track to experience its highest measles case count in over three decades, a stark reminder of the fragility of herd immunity. While recent outbreaks in Ohio and Minnesota garnered headlines, a growing cluster of cases in Kentucky – and similar reports from Utah – points to a more nuanced and potentially alarming trend: a significant portion of the population, particularly those born between the 1950s and 1960s, may lack adequate protection. This isn’t simply a matter of unvaccinated individuals; it’s a case of waning immunity and a generation potentially needing a booster, a scenario public health officials haven’t widely anticipated.
The Kentucky Outbreak: A Warning Sign Kentucky’s recent surge, now impacting Fayette and Woodford counties, isn’t isolated. The state has confirmed multiple cases, prompting health officials to urge residents to review their vaccination records. But the focus on current vaccination status overlooks a critical demographic. Individuals born in the 1950s and 60s often received a killed measles vaccine, which proved ineffective and was replaced with the live attenuated vaccine in 1963. Many in this cohort were never properly immunized, and even those who were may have waning immunity after decades. This creates a vulnerable population susceptible to infection and capable of spreading the virus.
Why the 1950s & 60s Cohort is at Risk The historical context is crucial. The shift from the killed vaccine to the live vaccine represents a significant gap in protection for a large segment of the population. While a single dose of the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine is generally considered highly effective, immunity isn’t lifelong. For those who received the ineffective killed vaccine, or even a single dose of the live vaccine decades ago, protection may have diminished, leaving them vulnerable. This isn’t a failure of the current vaccination program, but a consequence of past practices and the natural decline of immunity over time.
Beyond Kentucky: A National Trend and Future Implications The situation in Kentucky is likely a harbinger of what’s to come across the nation. As the population ages, and as travel increases, the risk of re-emergence of vaccine-preventable diseases like measles will grow. The current outbreak highlights the need for proactive strategies, including targeted vaccination campaigns for those born in the 1950s and 60s. However, this raises logistical challenges: identifying and reaching this demographic, addressing potential vaccine hesitancy, and ensuring adequate vaccine supply.
The Role of Waning Immunity and Booster Strategies The concept of waning immunity is becoming increasingly important in vaccine strategy. We’re seeing similar discussions around tetanus, pertussis, and even COVID-19 boosters. The measles outbreak underscores the need to move beyond a “one-and-done” approach to vaccination and consider periodic boosters to maintain adequate protection throughout life. This will require significant investment in research to determine optimal booster schedules and the development of more durable vaccines. **Waning immunity** is no longer a fringe concern; it’s a central challenge for public health in the 21st century.
Furthermore, the rise of misinformation and vaccine hesitancy continues to complicate matters. Combating false narratives and building public trust in vaccines is essential to prevent further outbreaks. This requires a multi-faceted approach, including clear communication from public health officials, engagement with community leaders, and addressing the underlying concerns that drive vaccine hesitancy.
Measles Cases (US) 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 (YTD – June 24) Total Cases 1,282 59 49 121 644 150+ The Future of Measles Control: A Proactive Approach The current measles outbreak isn’t just a public health crisis; it’s a wake-up call. It demands a shift from reactive outbreak response to proactive disease prevention. This includes strengthening surveillance systems, improving vaccination rates across all age groups, and investing in research to develop more effective and durable vaccines. The focus must also expand to address the social determinants of health that contribute to vaccine hesitancy and disparities in access to care. Ignoring these factors will only exacerbate the problem and leave us vulnerable to future outbreaks.
Frequently Asked Questions About Measles Resurgence
What should people born in the 1950s and 1960s do? Individuals born in this timeframe should check their vaccination records. If they received a killed measles vaccine, or are unsure of their vaccination status, they should consult with their healthcare provider about receiving the MMR vaccine.
Is the current measles vaccine effective? Yes, the MMR vaccine is highly effective, providing approximately 97% protection against measles. However, immunity can wane over time, necessitating potential booster doses.
What are the long-term implications of declining measles immunity? Declining immunity increases the risk of large-scale outbreaks, potentially overwhelming healthcare systems and leading to serious complications, particularly in vulnerable populations like infants and immunocompromised individuals.
How can we improve vaccination rates? Improving vaccination rates requires addressing vaccine hesitancy through clear communication, building trust with communities, and ensuring equitable access to vaccines.
The resurgence of measles serves as a critical reminder that infectious diseases remain a constant threat. A proactive, data-driven, and equitable approach to vaccination is essential to protect public health and prevent future outbreaks. The lessons learned from the current situation must inform our strategies for years to come.
What are your predictions for the future of measles control? Share your insights in the comments below!
